awd_titl_txt: CAREER:   Researching Chemical and Optical Properties of Secondary Organic Aerosol and Effective Practices for Environmental Science Education
awd_abstract_narration:
This CAREER project is focused on investigating the relationship between the chemical and optical properties of secondary organic aerosol in the atmosphere. Secondary organic aerosols are small particles composed of compounds formed from the atmospheric transformation of volatile organic gases. This research is being conducted in an environmental chamber where the composition and optical properties of the aerosols (such as how they scatter or absorb light) can be measured as the conditions in the chamber change.  This information is critical for improving model estimates of the direct radiative forcing of secondary organic aerosol and for understanding how they create haze and influence climate.

The Faculty Early Career Development (CAREER) Program is a Foundation-wide activity that offers the National Science Foundation's most prestigious awards in support of junior faculty who exemplify the role of teacher-scholars through outstanding research, excellent education and the integration of education and research within the context of the mission of their organizations. 

Environmental chamber experiments are being conducted to study the dependence of the secondary organic aerosol (SOA) optical characteristics on parent hydrocarbon, nature and degree of oxidation, relative humidity, and chemical characteristics.  The oxidation experiments will involve reactions of hydrocarbons that are important SOA precursors influenced by urban, biomass burning, and biogenically influenced sources, in order to better represent the ambient SOA found in different environments. The oxidation schemes tested will involve different sources of photooxidation radicals and different levels of nitrogen oxides (NOx) to span a range of NOx-free, intermediate-, and high-NOx conditions during the SOA generation and aging processes. 

The educational objectives of the project are focused on supporting local high school teachers and future STEM (Science, Technology, Engineering and Math) teachers in their professional development, and improving the STEM related skills among high school students.

por.por_cntn:
In this project, we focused on investigating oxidation of different volatile organic compounds (VOC) to determine climate-relevant properties of the resulting secondary organic aerosols (SOA). The experiments were carried out in an environmental chamber, in the presence of hydroxyl-radical precursors (H2O2 or HONO), ultraviolet light, and variable levels of nitrogen oxides (NOx), ammonia (NH3), and relative humidity.

Under low NOx conditions, the biogenic VOCs (a-pinene, b-caryophyllene and longifolene) formed predominantly scattering aerosols at 375 nm. In the presence of high NOx, the SOA in these systems had slightly higher absorbing characteristic at 375, indicating some formation of brown carbon (BrC) aerosols. On the other hand, aromatic VOCs (1-methylnaphthalene and phenol) formed absorbing SOA under both low and high NOx conditions. Additionally, increase in NOx, NH3 and humidity all contributed to enhancements in SOA absorption from 1-methylnaphthalene. Investigating the SOA mass spectra revealed that contribution of organonitrates (ON) is higher in the presence of NOx. By considering the time evolution of the optical properties and tracers of chemical composition, we conclude that organonitrates/nitroaromatics alone could not explain the increased brownness of the SOA at 375 nm during these experiments. Instead, the increasing trend in absorption normalized by SOA mass concentration (i.e., MAC) during high NOx and high NH3 conditions was consistent with the trend in C2H2N+ fragment of the SOA, which was formed at even a faster rate under higher relative humidity. We believe this fragment is derived from products of the reactions between ammonia and carbonyl-containing oxidation products of 1-methylnaphthalene, and can act as a tracer for formation of nitrogen-containing organic compounds (NOCs) derived from reduced nitrogen species. Previous studies have demonstrated the change in SOA composition due to presence of ammonia while others have shown the presence of NOCs in biomass burning BrC. In this work, we highlight a pathway that can explain production of NOCs and relatively strong BrC involving reactions between the aromatic precursors and ammonia in biomass burning or urban emissions.

To better understand properties of SOA as they are formed in ambient air, we also performed oxidation experiments of mixtures of biogenic and aromatic species, namely longifolene and 1-methylnaphthalene, longifolene and phenol, and a-pinene and phenol under high-NOx, continuous injection mode. We compared the optical properties of the SOA in the single systems with those of the mixtures through measurements and predictions. As expected, the online MAC values of the mixture SOA (at 375 nm) were in between those of the pure components. We then calculated the fraction of each pure component in the mixture SOA using the mass spectra of the pure systems as a guide. Assuming that the MAC of the mixture is the linear combination of those of the pure components, scaled by their respective fractional contribution, we calculated the MAC of the mixture. The predicted MAC values for some mixtures were different than the measured values, indicating different chromophoric SOA components can be formed when mixtures of VOCs react together.

The wavelength dependence of extinction was explored in phenol+longifolene, toluene+longifolene, and 1methylnaphthalene SOA systems. SOA formed from 1-methylnapthalene resulted in greater wavelength dependence at comparable sizes than phenol or toluene, suggesting that while particle size affects this wavenelength dependence, it is not the only factor.

 We also determined the refractive index of SOA in the pure and mixture systems, assuming Mie theory. The real component (n) of the refractive index ranged from ~1.35-1.8 and the imaginary component (k) was ~0.001-0.08, depending on the actual system (with phenol oxidation under high NOx conditions leading to the most absorbing SOA). Traditionally, uncertainties in the RI values calculated through optical closure are determined by repeating closure calculations with extreme values of the measured optical properties or size distributions considering their respective uncertainties. However, as we demonstrate, depending on the value of the real and imaginary component of RI as well as the shape of the aerosol size distribution, such estimates of RI uncertainty may be grossly inaccurate, especially for the real component of the RI if aerosols are strongly absorbing (k=0.5) or highly scattering (n=1.8).

In summary, results of our project have shed light on several key climate-relevant properties of SOA from VOC systems typically found in the atmosphere. These properties can be used in models to more accurately determine the role of SOA on direct radiative forcing under different scenarios. These sets of experiments have also provided training opportunities for 2 BS, 3 MS and 3 PhD students in Environmental Sciences at UCR while also equipping a dozen of AP Environmental Science/Chemistry classrooms at high schools in California's Inland Empire with science kits to study stratospheric ozone, tropospheric smog, and SOA formation.
